headline: The golden age of space exploration  in pictures
text: An early prototype of a spacesuit being tested in the late 1950s in America Photograph: Erich Hartmann/Courtesy of WestLicht       Alan Shepard is prepared for flight on the Mercury-Redstone 3 mission in May 1961. Shepard was the first American in space Photograph: Courtesy of WestLicht       John Glenn ready for his Friendship 7 flight in February 1962. The picture is likely to have been taken by the photographer Ralph Morse Photograph: Courtesy of WestLicht       John Glenn and family at home. Life magazine photographer Ralph Morse was assigned to photograph the early US astronauts and their families in their homes, to give a human face to the Mercury space programme Photograph: Ralph Morse/Courtesy of WestLicht       Apollo 14 commander Alan Shepard Photograph: Courtesy of WestLicht       Flight prepapations for the Mercury-Redstone 4 mission, with astronaut Virgil 'Gus' Grissom in the Liberty Bell 7 flight module, in July 1961Photograph: Courtesy of WestLicht       Agena Target Vehicle, also referred to as Thus, part of the Gemini 12 mission in November 1966Photograph: Courtesy of WestLicht       An Apollo 12 crew member using a video camera on the moon in November 1969 Photograph: Courtesy of WestLicht       The Earth as seen from the moon during the Apollo 12 mission. Apollo 12 was the sixth manned flight in the Apollo programme and the second to land on the moon Photograph: Courtesy of WestLicht       An unidentified crew member emerges from Apollo 9. Commander James McDivitt, command module pilot David Scott and lunar module pilot Rusty Schweickart spent 10 days in low Earth orbit in 1969 Photograph: Courtesy of WestLicht       Astronaut Ed White spacewalking over southern California during the Gemini 4 mission in June 1965. White and James McDivitt circled the Earth 66 times in four days Photograph: Courtesy of WestLicht       Crew members Ed White and James McDivitt during pre-launch preparations for Gemini 4 in 1965. White was killed January 1967 with fellow astronauts Gus Grissom and Roger Chaffee during pre-launch testing for Apollo 1, when fire broke out in their capsule Photograph: Courtesy of WestLicht       Training in the US for Apollo 17 in December 1972, the last moon landings Photograph: Courtesy of WestLicht       Wernher von Braun, the technical driving force behind the US space programme in the 1950s and 60s Photograph: Courtesy of WestLicht       Gordon Cooper and Charles 'Pete' Conrad in high spirits aboard a US navy recovery ship after their Gemini 5 flight in August 1965 Photograph: Courtesy of WestLicht       At the time, Nasa called Apollo 15 the most successful manned flight ever achieved. Commander David Scott and lunar module pilot James Irwin spent three days on the moon Photograph: Courtesy of WestLicht       A geological survey walk on the moon in December 1972, the last Apollo mission Photograph: Courtesy of WestLicht
